bibdata.title: Include 10 events in seeds of database

comments.body: @hackartisan Not being able to create video derivatives is going to make implementing the rest of the features a challenge. Perhaps we could put a gaurd in the `valid?` method so derivatives won't generate when deployed to production? Another option, I guess, is to merge this into a "video" branch instead of main.
Maybe we could put a temporary environment flag on some aspect of the manifest? Like it doesn't include the member files in production if it's a video?

princeton_ansible.title: First steps to nginx config template

comments.body:
Next (final?) steps for current PR:
- [x] backup config directories for easy rollback
- [x] run nginx -t after main config tasks are done
- [x] ~~if nginx -t fails, restore prior config from the backed up directories~~

Future work before we move our most complicated sites to the config template:
- [ ] engineer this so we can, from a branch, test our configs without going live - so for a test run we could just put config in non-active directories for comparison and debugging
Workflow for migrating a site from static to templatized config would then be:

1. open a branch, add vars to make the templatized config
2. run playbook from branch with the flag or other solution to output all configs to a non-working directory
3. compare static and templatized configs and do any needed debugging
4. delete static config on branch once things look good
5. run the playbook from branch "for realz" to affect actual working config

More progress today. When the `nginx -t` verification fails, instead of doing an automated recovery from the backed-up config directory, we decided it's better to post a message with the failure message - something like:
`Nginx config update failed. Time to get a human involved, please restore from <dir>.`

tiger-data-app.title: Fix mediaflux query to include all children and sub-collections

comments.body:
> @carolyncole it looks like there is a reason we are not using the `:collection` parameter to query. There is a bug in Mediaflux that prevents pagination from working when we use the `:collection` parameter.
> 
> See note here: https://github.com/pulibrary/tiger-data-app/blob/main/app/models/mediaflux/http/query_request.rb#L51-L53
> 
> You can reproduce the bug as follows:
> 
> ```
> asset.query :collection 1098 :idx 3 :size 3
>  :id -version "1" "1099"
>     :id -version "1" "1100"
>     :id -version "1" "1101"
>     :cursor
>         ...
> 
> asset.query :collection 1098 :idx 4 :size 3
>     :id -version "1" "1099"
>     :id -version "1" "1100"
>     :id -version "1" "1101"
>     :cursor
>         ...
> ```
> 
> Notice how Mediaflux returned the exact same asset ids even when we asked for the second page of results.

@hectorcorrea I did not change it to `:collection` because there is a bug.  `:collection` queries both the collection and all sub collections, so the old code was not equivalent to `:collection`. You need `asset in collection or subcollection of` to mimic the responses you getback when `:collection` is included.  This is ONLY an update to make the work around in our code work the same way as the `:collection`. I am unsure what your objection is.  This is truely confusing...  There is still the additional where clause.  I abosolutely did not change that.  Otherwise the PR would show it...
I can not understand @hectorcorrea's objections, but closing because he will fix the code

comments.body:
Carolyn found this: 
> If you start up that conatiner in any other way than in our documentation you get and error arc.mf.licence.ExInvalidLicence: The licence at file:/usr/local/mediaflux/config/licence.xml cannot be used: not a licence for this host. Expected '02:42:ac:11:00:02' but found the following ids [02:42:ac:11:00:03]
I'm putting this down for now until we get more clarity about whether this will be possible.
https://circleci.com/docs/building-docker-images/#run-docker-commands-using-the-docker-executor may help
